brief_summary.textblock: The ESP Study will evaluate the role of a novel pain measure and computer-based platform to screen for pain routinely in primary care settings at the VA Greater Los Angeles, Portland, and Minneapolis VAMCs. ESP will consider not only the effectiveness of the novel pain measures vs. usual care and the role of patient-reported versus clinician-documented pain but also evaluate how pain screening can be more effectively linked to pain management and consider how a technology platform can be implemented effectively in VA general practice settings.

detailed_description.textblock:
The "Pain as the Fifth Vital Sign" Initiative is a prominent feature of the VA's pain strategy. It focuses on current pain intensity by querying patients about "pain right now." In acute care settings (i.e, post-operative), assessment of current pain intensity allows clinicians to provide appropriate and timely analgesia and adjust treatment to achieve effective near-term pain control. In contrast, assessment of current pain intensity may have less relevance in primary care and other outpatient settings where many patients with pain have ongoing pain conditions and where functional impact may have greater clinical significance.
Pain problems in primary care are diverse, but the chronic conditions, back and osteoarthritis pain, are responsible for most of the burden of pain in primary care and require a long-term management approach. Structured repeated assessment is needed to evaluate the effectiveness of chronic pain management strategies, the benefits of which may accrue over months or years. Discrepancy between the information provided by the current pain screening approach and type of pain assessment information needed in primary care may be an important reason for the limited benefits of pain screening in primary care to date.
We previously found that pain screening often misses clinically important chronic pain in primary care. Several measures perform better than the 0-10 Numeric Rating Scale, or 'NRS now.' We have validated the three item PEG, derived from the Brief Pain Inventory, as an alternative to the 'NRS now'. A major advantage of the PEG is inclusion of emotional and physical function, as well as pain intensity. Furthermore, adherence to screening process is low, with informal approaches (e.g., "are you hurting?") being used in 50% of encounters instead of elicitation of a numeric value. Finally, pain screening does not address dimensions of pain, such as emotional or physical interference, which clinicians often find relevant. These problems illuminate why clinicians don't act on pain, even when it's of moderate-severe intensity.
Although screening may be improved by a more sensitive measure that includes functional aspects (e.g., the PEG), improving clinician adherence to screening processes is likely to be difficult. Direct patient reports of symptoms offer an alternative screening approach with momentum outside of VA due to the Patient Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) effort; underscoring the need to compare PRO vs. clinician assessment directly. An empiric study can also consider clinicians' views of how to link a new screening approach to management and formatively evaluate other implementation challenges (e.g., kiosk throughput. Results can prospectively inform improvement to the VA's '5th vital sign'. The ESP Project will test a new, better measure of pain using a computer kiosk, evaluate that measure versus what is in use now (e.g. 5th Vital Sign) and consider the barrier to implementing and using the new measure widely.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All Veterans are eligible to participate in the clinical trial when presenting for routine care in the primary care clinic at all sites (VA at Greater Los Angeles, Minneapolis, and Portland).
- All are eligible who do not opt out of participation.
- All participants in the baseline kiosk intervention will also be eligible for a one week follow up telephone interview - unless they are unable to complete a phone interview (see exclusions).
- For the qualitative Veteran component, all Veterans who can hear and respond in an interview are eligible.
- All primary care providers and staff in any of the three sites (GLA, Minneapolis, Portland) will be eligible to participate in provider interviews/focus groups.
- Providers/staff must be clinic and facility staff including administrative clerks, regular part time or full time employees in primary care who routinely participate in the care of Veterans who have painful conditions.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Veterans who meet either of the following exclusion criteria that may interfere with outcome assessment will be ineligible for the follow up telephone evaluation:
- a) no working telephone (home, office, or mobile)
- b) moderately severe cognitive impairment, defined as greater than or equal to 3 errors on a brief cognitive screener
- c) hearing impaired and unable to complete a phone survey
